author: oobdoo

description.text:
I wanted to mount my Arduino to the Spherebot without using zip ties. So here are some mounts to do just that. They use M3x10 bolts and I put a washer inbetween the nut and the mount. There are only 3 mounts because I originally designed this for a Duemilanove and it only has three holes.
Printed in Black ABS on my Prusa Mendel with Heated Bed.
Also included is the DWG I designed them in.

Print out the mounts and assemble as in the pictures. This should fit 5/16" rod and 8mm. I always have trouble printing little things like this. A way I found that works great is the set your skirt distance to something like 0.2mm and set your loops to 10ish and layers to 1. This makes a sudo raft and it comes off really easily. If you do this, I would suggest printing each part separatly so a skirt is made around the whole part. I have included a separate as well as nested STL of the mounts. The motor shield is from iTead: http://iteadstudio.com/store/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=18&products_id=520 It does 8th microstepping, but doesn't have enable pins. So you can't turn the motors on or off via gcode. But it does the job.

comments.text: Hie, do you have the firmware that you are using to drive the itead shield. If so, can you please upload it please so I can also use it for my eggbot

title: Gopro to Lego mounting plate adapters

description.text:
After making the Gopro tripod the other day I was thinking of other ways to hold the gopro and thought that it might be useful to be able to mount the camera to lego, my son has loads so was a good excuse to play with lego for a day.
I started with some parts already on thingivese made from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:591
I made the 5x5 block mount first as it was a bit bigger all round than the mounting plate,it came out well and I then used some lego to make it into a makeshift dolly.
The only problem with the 5x5 is that most lego blocks are even numbered so it dose not fit nicley to other parts but it depends what you want to do with it, as a base its nice and sturdy.
I then made the 4x4 block which is much smaller and lighter and uses less plastic which is no bad thing.
I made a dolly with both mounts but sure others will come up with some nice uses for it.
Have fun and get printing, hope to see some make on this one ;) Please don't sell this on or take my pictures with out asking.

The underside of these blocks is quite fine so I printed mine at 0.2 layer and 100% fill as the walls are thin.
I Printed mine in natural PLA but would print just fine in ABS which is what lego is made of.
I printed with a raft to support the under side of the clip part, the lego base prints ok without support so some of you could probably print ok without .

comments.text: I tried building 2 of the 4x4.  Used the recommended settings of 0.2 layer and 100% fill.  Unfortunately, both of them won't snap into the lego bricks.  Please advise.

title: Sensory Fidget Spinner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My daughter is developmentally disabled and on the Autism spectrum. I also have the privilege of working with a number of students across my school district that have Autism and other sensory needs. This fidget is the first of a few designs we made for our students with specials needs. It uses a standard skate bearing (8mm x 22mm x 7mm) in the middle. Each of the sides has a different texture that students can feel. Many of our students (including my daughter) enjoy rolling the fidget on their arms and hands.

If you have any other ideas or suggestions, please let me know in the comments below.

LulzBot

Mini

No

Take on the role of an antiques appraiser and research this artifact. Which president is associated with this artifact and what presidential power does it represent? The more information you provide, the more valuable the artifact.

This 3D printable model was created by a student in Ms. Relator's US Government class at Dominion HS in Virginia. Find out more about the Mystery Artifact lesson at https://www.lcps.org/Page/186358

Mystery artifact created by,

Linh Nguyen

Read the clues to find out what the object is and which president represent it.

Clues
1) The object was used by the veterans after WW1.
2) There was a popular protest, in which people stayed in these in the summer of 1932
3) The president ordered the army to destroy these

Notice
Which president is being represented here?
Which of the conflict is the president is part of?
How is it important to the United States history?

The Object:
Bonus Army Tent

Details about the object:
The Bonus Army tent was used by the veterans when they protest for their demand of cash-payment redemption for their service in WW1. President Herbert Hoover, made an order to use the army to break up the protester peacefully. However, a general mistaken the order and used force on the citizen, burning down all tents and killed innocent civilians nearby, including people who are protesters.

President:
Herbert Hoover
served from 1929-1933
Republican Party

Presidential Role:
Commander in Chief

Executive Action:
Proclaimed to use force on the veterans that are protesting if they don't break up themselves. On Jul 28, 1932, veterans who fought in WW1 demand cash-payment redemption for their service. Originally it wasn't distributed until 1945, but when the Great Depression hit all of the former veterans were forced out of work and demand the early payment. Veterans used the teepee to camp outside of Washinton D.C as they were protesting.

Impact on America:
In the third term of president Herbert Hoover, he was dealt with a conflict with the veterans who wanted their early demand cash-payment, later known as the Bonus Army conflict. The conflict devastated the United States on how they treated their veterans and it is a pitiful event that happened.

"I choose this object because it represents this very important act by the President"
As one his first act on the conflict, president Herbert Hoover decision was to used military forces against the protester. During the conflict, many citizens died due to evacuation and
outraged the people across the states. I wanted to research this president because he is a very benevolent person and he wanted to end hunger in Europe after WW1. His height of success started when he entered the oval office for the first two years, but it became pitiful when the Great Depression hit the United States."

Works Cited:

Bonus Army. (2017, February 23). Wikipidia. Retrieved February 28, 2017, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bonus_Army

The 'Bonus Army' War in Washington. (2016, August 09). History.net. Retrieved March 03, 2017, from http://www.historynet.com/the-bonus-army-war-in-washington.htm

The Bonus Army. (n.d.). Eyeswitness.com. Retrieved February 28, 2017, Retrieved from http://www.eyewitnesstohistory.com/snprelief4.htm

description.text:
Take on the role of an antiques appraiser and research this artifact. Which president is associated with this artifact and what presidential power does it represent? The more information you provide, the more valuable the artifact.

This 3D printable model was created by a student in Ms. Relator's US Government class at Dominion HS in Virginia. Find out more about the Mystery Artifact lesson at https://www.lcps.org/Page/186358

Mystery Artifact by
Kiara Beltran

This object was used by the president of the United States and the leader of the Soviet Union.
This object represents an important discussion about the United States and a Caribbean country.
This object was used 13 days in October 1962.

The Object:
Red Telephone.

Details about the Object:
Red Telephone with white button in the middle.

President:
John F. Kennedy (1961-1963) Democratic Party

Presidential Role:
Chief Diplomat

Executive Action:
President Kennedy stopped the Cuban Missile Crisis from continuing. He made an agreement with the Soviet leader to stop all missiles from being sent out. John F. Kennedy and Nikita Khrushchev used this telephone to communicate about the issues that they were facing.

Impact on America:
**Why was the Cuban Missile Crisis important?

I chose this President and artifact because it shows a strong leader doing his duty to protect his country and the object that helped make this happen. I wanted to research this president because I wanted to know more about him and his life while being president. I also wanted to become more aware of what was going on in the United States when he was president.

Works Cited

History.com Staff. (2010). Cuban Missile Crisis. Retrieved March 01, 2017, from
http://www.history.com/topics/cold-war/cuban-missile-crisis

T. (n.d.). Rotary Phone by MicrosoftStore. Retrieved March 01, 2017, from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:556612

View of downtown Atlanta from the back gardens. - Picture of Carter Center, Atlanta - TripAdvisor. (n.d.). Retrieved March 01, 2017, from https://www.tripadvisor.com/LocationPhotoDirectLink-g60898-d589770-i42305346-Carter_Center-Atlanta_Georgia.html There Never Was Such a Thing as a Red Phone in the White House. (2013, June 18). Retrieved March 01, 2017, from http://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/there-never-was-such-a-thing-as-a-red-phone-in-the-white-house-1129598/

This 3D printable model was created by a student in Ms. Relator's US Government class at Dominion HS in Virginia. Find out more about the Mystery Artifact lesson at https://www.lcps.org/Page/186358

In Government class we were assigned to do a mystery artifact project for a president of our choice. Once you have a president you have to research them to find something significant about them that we could make into a 3-D object.

Mystery Artifact by Zaria Meekins

1) I heard that my President fought in the Mexican-American War.
2) He was a respected president because of his ties with the war.
3) My President didn’t not last very long in office; he died shortly after being elected.

The Object:
A chair on top of a row of skulls
From a Political Cartoon

President:
Zachary Taylor
Served:1849-1850
Whig Party

Presidential Role:
Commander-in-Chief

Pre-Executive Action:
The chair perched atop the skulls is to symbol President Zachary Taylor fighting in the Mexican-American war. The reasoning behind him sitting in the chair on top of the skulls is to depict the lives lost in the war. The skulls are there to represent the Mexican-American War casualties that happened during the fight.
Executive Action: ***Find out what Taylor did with Mexico once President, hint slavery

Impact of the United States:
The war was thought of as a “Manifest Destiny” by US president Polk who fought alongside with Taylor. When the war was over Mexico had lost 1/3 of its territory which included California, Utah, Nevada, Arizona, and New Mexico. After the war was over the United States soldiers were happy because they had fought the Mexicans and they had won and had gained new territory.

Works Cited:

History.com Staff. (2009). Mexican-American War. Retrieved March 01, 2017, from http://www.history.com/topics/mexican-american-war

Alexander, R. (2016). Manifest Destiny [Slide Presentation]. Retrieved March 01, 2017, from http://slideplayer.com/slide/6840112/
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Whig_primary_1848d.jpg

Buttons
the 8 buttons per Arduinio gave us plenty of digital input pins. we no longer needed shift registers, and could use a simplified button circuit:
http://www.arduino.cc/en/Tutorial/Button RGB LEDs
the lighting control came after much experimentation with very bright RGB LEDs. These were broken out to their own board with independent power supply. the Arduino could not drive the high powered LEDs and placement needed to be more flexible. The Arduino controls the RGB values via three PWM pins and a common ground. The values are reversed due to the odd relays we acquired. (ie {R=256,G=256,B=0} is BLUE) Midi-out
midioutThe midi-out circuit is very straight forward with only two connected pins and a dangling ground. These wires are thin and continually come loose and cause trouble. PCB
Fritzing.org has wonderful layout software that was used to generate the green image above. Soon they\'ll support eagle export, which will open up the design to any board shop. AndrÃ© KnÃ¶rig has been an amazing resource by helping with the PCB routing and our submission into the Fritzmas contest.

description.text:
Tidier and very sturdy mount for a Bowden extruder. Designed specifically for Anet A8. Lines up nicely with your hot end too.

Requires:

2 M3x25
1 M3x20
The two original M3x18 from the Anet A8 frame

The toothed wheel should be brought forward by 5mm with the smallest supplied allen key.

The centre hole is 24mm wide so up to you if you use supports.
I print nearly all my parts in 50% density so again up to you what your preferred infill is.
Printed in PLA so 'as is' 100% scale in Cura

Edit: Added left side mount.
Edit: Added original 123D file for remixing

Caution for US users:
The bowden fitting for original and clone E3Dv6's seems to be an imperial larger fitting and will not fit. The correct fitting is a PC4-M6.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50

comments.author: alexylem

comments.text: So I've been using this for a few months now with no problems. Lately I've noticed that the idler arm will not sit flush against the bracket. Eventually causing the filament to strip and stop extruding. All hardware is tight and I didn't see any signs of wear on the bracket itself. I'm using the original extruder parts from the a8, apart from the new screws. I was just wondering if you've experienced this before?
comments.author: Moarmau5

comments.text:
Hmm I think I did have an issue of it stripping the PLA once after I hadn't used it in a while but like the rest of the machine, it just needed tuning from the ground up again. I believe I tightened the idler arm and looosened the guide bearing to give it slight diagonal play. Just looked at mine and there is actually a 1mm gap between the spring/thumb bolt and the bracket. I suppose stronger plastic (to withstand the torsion wear from the spring) or redesigning with an outer face plate added would be ideal.
Printing it with too low an infill could definitely cause it to fail over time.
comments.author: Moarmau5

comments.text: Thanks for the reply! Possibly my infill was too low. It's been a while since I've printed it, so I can't remember the settings. But I ended up mounting everything on the back side of the mount, so the extruder is against the stepper and it's been working like a charm! The hole previously for the stepper shaft to go through is now a nice view port for the filament :).

comments.text: My design is made of 5mm thick plastic. When you stick the motor in, you'll see the gear/cog/toothed wheel isn't sticking out enough. There is a tiny grub screw that keeps the toothed wheel attached to the motor. Use those little L shaped metal tools that came with the printer (called Allen keys) to loosen the grub screw and slide the toothed wheel out by 5mm. Tighten the grub screw and you're all good.

description.text:
TINY SPRING REVOLVER:

  • SHOOTING AIRSOFT AMMOS (6mm)
  • 10 m SHOOTING RANGE (at least)

This is a miniature working model of a revolver, based on an internal spring (not printable).
The model does not require glue neither external components (except for the spring) for working.

CAUTION! You will need an IRON SPRING to make the model working. Here the specifics:

  • Max lenght = 15 mm
  • Min lenght (compressed) = 9 mm
  • Max external diameter = 8 mm

Such a spring can be obtained from a common CLOTHESPIN.

Standard ammos for this model are common 6 mm diameter balls for airsoft guns, but you can print or create your own ammos as well, if you want to.

PRINTING ADVICES:

The model was realized with PLA, but it should be fine also for ABS.

The model was created for a low cost 3D printer, so the quality of my own printing is not excellent, although the model is working fine. For that reasion the project was made without taking into account any tolerance in joint and complementary parts, so any user can adapt his own printing to the quality of his 3D printer.

Consequently, some some RASP and SANDPAPER WORK is REQUIRED in order to complete the model. Sorry for the inconvenience.

Model files are numbered in the recommended printing sequence. The model is fully functional with the first four parts:

1) Body
2) Piston
3) Trigger
4) Lock

I advice you to print these four parts in order to verify if your printing is working fine.
The first one, named BODY, is quite complex and requires SUPPORT and correct orientation for obtaining a good result.

The next parts have an aestethic or accessory functions; in particular the piece called LOADING ROD is to be located inside the gun's handle, and is useful for reloading the gun.

OPERATING INSTRUCTIONS

For using the model simply:

  • Push back the piston by the front of the barrel using the loading rod
  • Make sure the trigger locks the piston correctly
  • Insert the ammo inside the front of the barrel and push it inside
  • Aim and press the trigger

MAKE SURE YOU DON'T AIM TO PEOPLE OR ANIMALS, THE SHOT CAN BE SURPRISINGLY POWERFUL FOR SUCH A TINY TOY GUN AND COULD BE DANGEROUS FOR EYES

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

The smaller pieces need 100% infill, the BODY requires a strong structure but a minor infill is also ok

Notes:

Printing the BODY is quite complex, you will need support, raft and a correct orientation. Experimenting is welcome. I printed it vertically with the barrel sticked to the bedprint, to improve internal barrel quality.

There are a lot of matching parts, and you will need to clean and sandpaper them a lot for making them match. I didn't consider any tolerance because it should be related to your own printing quality, so that model can be printed both using low and high quality printers

ONE STEEL SPRING
  • Max lenght = 15 mm
  • Min lenght (compressed) = 9 mm
  • Max external diameter = 8 mm
    • Can be easily obtained from a CLOTHESPIN

I printed out the design by na427, but the lip was obstructing the cell phone's screen. I liked the design otherwise, so I decided to remix it.  
The design has been made from scratch using SolidWorks 2013, following roughly the dimensions and design of the original stand. I also made the angle of the phone a few degrees less steep, and added fillets to the bottom corners to prevent warping.  
It have tested the design with Nexus 5, Nexus 4, Galaxy Nexus and Galaxy S4. Most modern smartphones will work great with it, both in landscape and portrait positions.  
Tip: Scale it a bit wider to make a great stand for bigger tablets! The original dimensions are good for slim 7" tablets, such as the Nexus 7.

title: Clip-on Lack Table Braces for Wanhao i3/Maker Select

description.text:
Having bought myself a Wanhao i3 and a couple of Lack tables from ikea I wanted to secure the printer down to stabilise the Z axis.

I didn't want to be drilling and I didn't have any hardware or rods to hand. So this is entirely screwless (though there are screw holes) it clips on to the . The one thing I did do is hot glued the top brace to the underside of the table to stabilise the Z axis.

It now prints beautifully!

I also incorporated a little cable holder for the cables at the back if you need to keep them down (not the heat bed, that needs to be free).

This is a printable pattern I've been using to check if my print bed and first layer settings are properly set. I find it more useful for filaments that don't like sticking to the bed.  
Note: Certain versions of Repetier Host miss some of the little pieces of the circle. To fix this, select "Fix Normals" before slicing. (Checked on v1.0 beta.)

The large pattern is used right after you have finished leveling your print bed (or if you think there is something wrong with your print bed). The small pattern is useful if you think a certain part of your print bed is not level. See the instructions for the part that inspired this one, as it is used the same way: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:111720
Recommended tools:
  • Tweezers to keep junk from building up on your bed if something isn't set correctly
  • Something to cancel the print or turn off your printer quickly before things get ugly
    Essentially, you do the following:
    1. Set your print bed such that it is NOT TOO CLOSE to your hot end. (You don't want your print head crashing in to the table - by experience!)
    2. Set your printer to print one of the patterns with NO bed adhesion aids (e.g. no raft, no brim, no supports, no skirt).
    3. Be ready to cancel the print, and start printing the pattern.
    4. If the pattern does not look like circles or the filament drags when your printer is turning the corner, re-adjust and try printing the pattern again.
      Tweaks:
  • You can set the diameter with objDiam if you have a bigger or smaller bed
  • Height should be your first layer height
  • ringthickness should be big enough that your printer has to do more than one pass for each segment

title: Mobile Frame Zero: Shinonome SN-2 "Kishi"
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
"After months of successful combat with SN-0s and SN-1Hs, the mechs began to experience a fall from grace as more and more enemies discovered their weak spots. The SN-0 could not operate underwater due to barometric pressure breaching waterproofing seals, nor in low-atmosphere environments, and because the SN-1H could not be transported by air because of its mass, it had to be assembled at ground stations, which were subsequently raided. Shinonome Frame Corporation's next mech, or "suit", as it is called within the company, is a tour de force able to eliminate foes on land, in the air, in space, and in water up to 500 metres deep. However, the SN-2 "Kishi" is an intense drain on resources, and rightfully so, only five examples have been built and awarded to Shinonome's most decorated pilots. The SN-2 comes equipped with an automatic SN-GC carbine rifle and a battle-forged sword identical to the SN-0's; "If it ain't broke, don't fix it". Both can be stored on the SN-2's back, but if stored together (which is seldom done), the sword's hilt is to be inserted into the SN-GC's scope. Flight is achieved by thrusters in the shoulders, in pods that extend from the arms, and in the two large pods on the back. These "wings" also contain fuel and oxygen tanks (although the oxygen tanks are only needed for environments with little to no oxygen). The SN-2 is also capable of using all previous Shinonome weapons."

Obvious Gundam influence is obvious. My largest Mobile Frame to date (while my other ones took me an afternoon each, this took two).
From left to right (in LXF file): skeleton, armed with sword, armed with carbine, "Ancient" reskin (of which only one exists in the MFZ setting).

TIPS:
-Careful when posing - hip joints are fragile but can be reinforced with two 85861s.
-The ankles can bend in and out, even if LDD says otherwise.
-Lateral shoulder joints are very snug and need some force to move.

Systems
Defense: Hand-to-Hand
Movement: Flight
Surveillance: N/A
Melee: Sword (or SN-1H's Battle Hammer)
Direct Fire: Automatic Carbine (or SN-1H's Rotary Machine Gun)
Artillery: N/A (or SN-0's Sniper Rifle)
x0 Single-Shot Rockets

For more info on Mobile Frame Zero, a Lego-based wargame: http://mobileframezero.com/mfz/

description.text:
Hi! I modified the original moveo to improve some problems and get a better robot arm

IMPORTANT I DID NOT TEST ALL THE PARTS THAT I MODIFIED ANY FEEDBACK COULD BE GOOD

READ THE LAST LINE TO GET MORE INFORMATION OF THE BUILDING PROBLEMS

26/10/2017
Improvements
Just added my new axis 1 base with tensioner for the belt and a bigger size of the axis to make the cables go throught it
Added a fast harting connection in the axis 1 base
Added and extra port on the other side to put extra connections
Added a 3d printeable axis1 (my idea was to do one in aluminum with a lathe)
If you change de belt for a closed one robot will be able to rotate up 360º

Axis 5 reinforcement (RentaPrinter told that we have some issues with this part)

Improvements! (old)
-Just added the 6 axis.
-Added fixed linear axis to get a location system (potientiometers) in the future.
-Added a soft mechanical end.
-Fix point to get the dress pack fixed (electrical wiring).
-Improved 4 axis for more stable movement.
-Belts cover to get a more fluid design.
-Improved bearings covers to get a fluid design.
-Oversized axis 1 joint to get cables go throught it
-New one piece base to get a more stable and rigid and versatile robot.

Future Improvements!!!
-Get the axis 1 go more than 360 degrees.
-Create a locate position for each axis.
-Create the belts with smart flex fil. (Fail)
-See down to see how the finish product will be.

My idea is to have a robot arm conected to a power closet (arduino and stepper controller)
The closet could have inputs and outputs to actuate to envoirment

The robot will be controled with a raspberry pi with his own system for movement .Robot will be able to be programed as joint (moved axis by axis) or linear moved through a base frame referenced by the base of the robot.
Maybe could put tool frames
You could activate desactivate and compare data and I/O

i would like to make the most similar as i can of an industrial robot arm as Fanuc,ABB,KUKA,etc.

Maybe in a future i would make a rack or slide to mount robot on it.

Maybe it could be interesting to show you how the actual industrial robots are programed.
"
"
Extra info for the modifications
Axis 4 i just modified de lock of the the nut puting the nut locked bettwen the 2 machined nylon or metal washers.if you see the nylon washer has to go into the rail and then go down to get locked into a 2mm pocket and the same for the other side.the inner mesure of the nylon washer has to be nicely ajusted to the engine axis to not get any movement.The nut has to fit into the two washers.

comments.text:
By complete coincidence, I ordered a 5mm shaft "mounting hub" from the openbuilds part store the other day, and then completely forgot about it until it showed up today. I mainly bought it just to see if it would be useful, but it looks like it will actually be pretty much ideal for this situation. Instead of a hexagon, it's actually a square block with 2 setscrews and 4 holes for mounting bolts. I've gone ahead and redesigned the 6 axis and it's insert to be able to accommodate it. I'll print it tomorrow and if it works well I'll post a project remix for that axis. For now I've attached the prototype files though. The mounting hub thing is here:
http://openbuildspartstore.com/mounting-hub-5mm/
It only costs $4 or so, so I think it will be a viable solution. I did have to extend the front of the axis out about 3mm to make it all fit, but I think it will still work. You still mount the main axis to it using the same m3 bolt setup, just moved slightly in towards the center. So for assembly you would put the nuts in the back of the lobed thing, put the square block in the lobed thing, slide that assembly up the motor shaft, lock it in place with the two setscrews, then set the motor and assembly into the front section and attach 4 possibly 12mm now M3 bolts. Maybe 14's. Not sure yet. The rest of the assembly would remain unchanged. It looks like it will work anyways, and the part is dirt cheap so I am hopeful!
comments.author: labala

Sure, send me anything you have on the idea and I'll see if i can make it work! piercet @ comcast.net if you prefer e-mail

comments.text:
Hello again. I've got most of the large sections printed now, still printing stage 1 and 4, here's some feedback so far.
Overall everything prints cleanly, even in ABS. The inner flat section of the arms on either side of the rotery sections could benifit from a bit of a rounding there to ease lifting, but nothing major. I did experience a few minor issues.
Axis 2: The shaft hole for the bearings is exactly 8.00mm. to ease post processing it might be better to oversize that slightly since the bearings will be holding the shaft, not the plastic.
Axis 3. The concealment door is a very, very, very tight fit. I had to trim it considerably to get it to go in. it fits fine now, but taking .2mm off the outer edges would be helpful
Axis 5. The uppermost corner recess is really really thin here, and printed with only partial connection. I was able to salvage it, and i'm not sure how you could improve it much without a major redesign of the Axis 4 segment to allow for additional clearance, but it's something to be aware of. If clearance allows I would consider adding 2-3mm to the diameter of the Axis 6 cuff piece at least to stabilize that part

comments.text:
This CTC Prusa i3 printer is a copy of the printer from Geeetech (specifically "Geeetech Prusa i3 Pro B") and probably therefore should be compatible with the firmware from Geeetech (Marlin 1.0.2 Stable). For the board GT2560 you need search the file Marlin-PI3_Pro_B.zip in this thread:
https://www.geeetech.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=20&t=17046
or download it directly from this link:
https://www.geeetech.com/forum/download/file.php?id=2819
comments.author: BritVic

comments.text: Hi a quick question about the firmware. Is it ok to download the firmware you have linked and flash it straight to the printer without any modification or will i need to change some things. I only want to reflash the firmware so i can turn on EEPROM functions.
comments.author: tom666

comments.text: Firmware from Geeetech has already enabled EEPROM support. You will not need to modify the code because CTC Prusa i3 printer is a hardware identical with the Geeetech Prusa i3 Pro B. However, the problem may occur because the bootloader on the board (GT2560 by CTC) has nonstandard setting of the communication protocol speed (Wiring Baud 57600). It will therefore be necessary to modify the file "boards.txt" in the Arduino IDE. Specifically, it is necessary to change the setting of the "mega.menu.cpu.atmega2560.upload.speed" for "Arduino / Genuino Mega w / ATmega2560" from the initial value 115200 to 57600.

title: Gantry Feet for Azza Z Brace Mod for Wanhao Duplicator i3, Monoprice Maker Select, and Cocoon Create

description.text:
The original gantry feet by TRAVMO weren't sized correctly for the Azza Z brace mod, which is the most popular of the Z brace mods.

The Azza Z brace mod requires a 3mm bottom. Also, Azza suggested that you put rubber feet on the bottom, so you need room for a foot.

This remix was remodeled from scratch with a 3mm bottom and room for a 3/4" (20mm) self-adhesive rubber foot.

No

Doesn't need the same strength as the main parts from the Azza mod, so I did 30% infill.

description.text:
Created a dual extrusion spinner but felt bad for everyone who does not have dual extrusion capabilities. Enter the modular tri spinner. Print one of the bottoms and one of the tops in any color you want. Then print 2 of the middle ones each in their own color. Voila, you have a multi color tri spinner.

Currently I have been touching the 4 parts with a soldering iron to fuse them. The bearing holds the center really well. I heat the bearing with a heat gun so it slides in easier. It is a snug fit. Wear gloves if you do that because the bearings to heat up really quick.

https://youtu.be/IdIqoV1Paow

Have fun and stay focused. =)

Printer Brand:

Deltaprintr

Printer:

Deltaprintr Assembled

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

5

Notes:

Super simple print. Made one where I printed parts on 3 different printers and they all meshed fine.
Tinkercad is my friend. The coolest new technique I used as holding Ctrl+Shift to resize parts around their center. That is an amazing trick when you have placed pins as I had in this project.

description.text:
Weight of bridge: 39g
Load held: 33kg(that's the maximum weight. We may hold more)
Load to weight ratio: 841
Members with 10% infill are 1.27, 1.8 and 2.012
Members with 15% infill are 0.9 and 2.846

i worked with Jeremy Zwingman on this project and it is a bridge with varying members of size and infill. the two different files represent the different types of infill of 25% or 50%. The total weight of our bridge was 20.5 grams and it had a weight to load ratio of over 1000 (1209). You have to be careful putting it together because the members have a tight friction fit, and removing them from shafts can be tricky. One of our members broke due to this and i believe that it would've been better if it didn't break.

A fidget spinner i designed myself
Uses 26 mm OD (Outside diameter) bearings these can be brought from here:
Ebay UK: https://goo.gl/T1IWaW
Ebay US: https://goo.gl/S9Fvok (Make sure to change the Quantity to 3)

description.text:
Hi,

this is a Filament Guide for an Ikea Table. In this Guide there is an PTFE Inliner (you need about 4-5cm of PTFE (Teflon)Tube) which will be pushed into the 3D printed part afterwards.

You need to drill an 8mm hole through the top of the Ikea table. For best results please use a piece of tape on the top and on the back of the spot where you drill into the table to prevent the surface from shattering.

I hope you like it, if you have any questions fell free to ask.

description.text:
A little model for a project of lamp i'm working on. I've remixed the work of Igotron with a more compact layout and I've hollowed the crystal so you can put a light source in the middle.

I printed my versions using transparent ABS at 200nm layer height. The left one has been polished with acetone but I find the non polidhed version more appealing.
The crystals' angles make any support removal verry easy, so don't be afraid to put some support in the middle of the print if need be.

Its only a start... but what oh!

I blew up the PIR in my Arduino starter set - a replacement was a quid, or 50 for 12quid(!). So I got 50 of em!!

I was going to add directional control to the RC Car I am designing/3d printing (other bits I've already uploaded) so though I'd experiment on directional IR tracking... so used 6 of the blighters in this thing, I am wiring up all the +5v and Common together than will put leads on the 6 sensors to go directly into arduino data pins and see if how directional it can be(!).

print_settings.Notes:: Using lower layer height than 0,25mm will of course work, but it won't add strength or any useful aspect, so I recommend 0,25mm for a speedy print which will work perfectly. (atleast for me with the standard Prusa i3 mk2.)

title: Train tracks for OS-Railway - fully 3D-printable railway system!

description.text:
OS-Railway is a complete railway kit in 1:45 scale (32mm track width) designed from the ground up to be fully 3D-printable! Everything from track, switches, locomotives and cars and accessories are specially designed to be printable.

Update 7/11/2017
Added several tracks, prepared build plates and a track-application tool that connects to the end of a track, for example via a turnout so you can easily add cars and locomotives to the track. I also fixed orientation on all the STL's so they end up correct in the slicer from the start.

Update 1/11/2017
Turnouts have been moved to a separate page to keep things more clear:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2619888

Update 8/4/2017
User McTimmi has made a configurable track page which is awesome! Check it out here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2221916 and you can make any length you want of the track!

Arc bridge and slope addon here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2172709

Truss bridge
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2624578

10 part Slope
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2631795

This is the page for track parts. Trains and other parts are uploaded to their own pages to avoid having too many files on one page

Locomotive in the picture: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2575667
Z70, a simple get-started locomotive: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2146425
Freight car chassis: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2152351
Freight car hopper addon: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2169327
Tanker car: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2235152
Passenger car: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2591362

Available now are:

100mm straight
200mm straight
300mm radius 30 degrees (need 12 to get a loop)
400mm radius 30 degrees (need 12 to get a loop)

The outbound track turns 30 degrees, so if you connect a 400mm radius 30-deg piece, it will line up with a 200mm straight so you get two parallel tracks.

The track gauge is 32mm (O-scale), however, 3D-printability is prioritized over scale. Here are some design aspects that have been adopted for 3D-printing:

  • Design for 100% infill. All structures (if not stated otherwise) are designed to use a minimum amount of material. The tracks for example, gets stronger and more flexible if you print them with 100% infill. They only consume about 1g/cm, which means you almost get 10meter track per kg roll! That probably beats most commercial track systems!

  • Designed for easy printing - There are many really nice models made for 3D-printing, but many of them require the printing of a large number of parts. In this system, the number of parts is strategically limited to minimize print time. The orientation and design of the parts is also specially made for the 3D printing process.

  • Avoiding support - the aim is to organize parts and split models in such a way that the requirement for support structure is removed, or at least very limited.

This is just the first parts, many more will be added later!

Printer:

Prusa i3 mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Using lower layer height than 0,25mm will of course work, but it won't add strength or any useful aspect, so I recommend 0,25mm for a speedy print which will work perfectly. (atleast for me with the standard Prusa i3 mk2.)

Track connection

If you feel that the tracks pieces are too difficult to connect, just sand or scrape with a knife on the parts until you get the result you want. Obvious, yes, but one thing that maybe isn't that obvious is that if you have a badly calibrated first layer, especially if it's squeezed, the extruded lines tend to be wider so you might need to trim it a bit. You can see this if you look at the bottom of the part if the edges stick out compared to the rest of the part.

comments.text: Hi, I don't own any other system that I can check compatibility with and I have designed this system for 3D-printing from the ground up which means I have to adapt a lot of things for the printing process. This means making sure I don't have geometries that are hard to print, structural parts that are too thin etc. The wheels are probably the thing that will cause trouble if you try to run my trains on another track, as I have to make the wheels thicker to make them strong enough. But I have left room for adjustment of the wheel width separation so if you can buy metal wheels and position them with the right wheel base you can probably use my trains and cars on another O-gauge system, but leave no guaranties. I'm not really a train nerd myself, so I don't have any other train systems except some old T-gauge stuff I bought years ago.

comments.text: Ok, yes most garden railway systems is G-scale (45mm) and I've gotten requests to adapt to that but it gets far too big when using it indoor in an apartment like I do, so I will stick to the 32mm gauge. But, scaling up in the printing process is always easier than scaling down, as you know that no walls or structures is going to be too thin to print, so you can probably get a good result for the 45mm gauge as long as the parts fits on your print bed, and of course, you have to check that the wheels are compatible. Only downside if you scale up is that the lack of small details will be more visible. I don't focus on getting all the small details on my creations as I focus more on functionality and to create a system rather than very detailed individual cars/locomotives.

title: Draw your Learning: Makerbot Printshop Tutorial

description.text: 3D printing through CAD (Computer Aided Design) allows students to design, print, and interact with their learning. However, most CAD tools take multiple class sessions to complete a design and will require a certain level content knowledge on the CAD tool you are using. The Shape Maker tool in the Printshop app allows for an the almost instantaneous production of students’ learning, and the best part is if they can draw, they can CAD!
NGSS

The following tutorial can be used to have students create the follow and much more…. Tessellations - Rulers - Geometric Shapes - Clock Faces - 5/10 Frames - Nets - Area vs. Perimeter Models - Graphs - Visual Fraction Models - Words for Foreign Language Learners - Protractors - Scientific Models (Image 1) Image 1

Shape Maker Within the Printshop app for iOS, there are many interactive CAD modeling tools that let students see how they can manipulate a 3D shape. For many students, this is a great first introduction to what CAD is. The Shape Maker section in the app allows for endless options in your student's designs. Outlined below is how to have your students in Kindergarten all the way through High School benefit from CADing through drawing. There are two main ways to have your students use Shape Maker. First through the use of graph paper (see link below), and second through free form drawing. Graph Paper There are many applications where you will want to have your students create their learning with the use of graph paper. Maybe you want your students to use the lines in math manipulative creation, or just to give a better reference for their drawings. However, you cannot use off-the-shelf graph paper for this. For example, if you has students draw an outline of a planned building on regular graph paper. (Image 2) Take a picture with the Shape Maker app of it. The 3D model would turn out looking like the bottom image in image 2 Not quite what you want! However, if you use the graph paper found in the Thing Files, you will be able to have models where the lines don’t show up. The lines are light enough for the app to not turn them into a shape but dark enough for your students to use them in their work. There is both a ¼ “grid and 1 cm grid paper. Image 2 Free Form Drawing If using graph paper is not what you need you can use plain white A4 paper. When having students draw their learning on the paper it is best to use dark and thick lines. This is best achieved with black, brown, blue, or purple broad tip or felt tip markers. Also, when you take the picture of drawing you want to make sure that only what you want to be turned into a 3D model gets captured in the shot. Anything in the cameras field of view i.e. tabletop, other drawings, will get turned into a 3D model as well. (Image 3) From a Drawing to a Picture to a 3D model ready for printing. Image 3 Additional options Once you have taken a picture with the shape maker app and the app has turned it into a 3D model you have 3 additional options to edit your model with. see image 4 1-Height
Use this tool to change the height of the model. 2-Backing
This tool gives you 4 different options for the back of your model. 3-Ind. Piece Height
You can use this tool to either delete individual pieces within your designs or to change different parts of your model to have varying heights. Image 4 Saving and Printing The Printshop app works hand in hand with the Makerbot Desktop or Makerbot Print software. When you set your desktop software up for the first time to run your Makerbot printer you will be prompted to set up a Makerbot account. You can use those same account details to register all of your schools iPADs with the Printshop apps. (Image 5) Image 5

Makerbot Printshop App - iOS only
Attached Graph Paper
Lessons will vary but all student creations can be designed and made in 1 class period.

description.text:
All the parts are printed with an infill of 35% as we believe this will make the bridge light and yet strong as possible.

The individual parts are available for print, if you need to reprint only one specific member, however you can also just print the last two files with multiple members to print all the necessary members at once.

The bridge weighs 25g (without the weight from the 11 metal joints used), held up to a weight of 37.2g making the load to weight ratio 1312.

Here is a video of the bridge being tested:
https://drive.google.com/a/students.mvcs.org/file/d/0Bw18wlz-RYnKY215eHVPM3Z6U3c/view?usp=sharing

Even though the base Y-Ends work well, I found that I needed to support the holes to handle more abuse and to extend the bed 'holders' to accommodate surfaces that might sag (like thin acrylic), on which you might mount something like a heatbed.  If you use a piece of wood, you don't need this, but because I am using my modified X-Plate, I have to use a thinner bed, which is prone to sagging.  So, I modified Serge's Y-Ends to extend them (I just duplicated them and added some blocks in TinkerCAD).  
UPDATE: I noticed and someone also pointed out, that there are hole and alignment issues with this.  I know, I know.  Right after I put this out, Serge modified the original version of this and that works fine.  I would suggest that this part is now deprecated and you should download the new one for SmartRap from the main site.

title: Z70 Locomotive for OS-Railway - fully 3D-printable railway system! Arduino-controlled!

description.text:
OS-Railway is a complete system of track, trains and accessories, all designed to be fully 3D-printable. The size is the same as O-scale (32mm track) but printability is prioritized over scale.

This page covers the Z70 locomotive, for track pieces see a separate page
Klick here for track: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2146361

Klick here for cars: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2152351

This locomotive was inspired by the Swedish lokomotor Z70 https://sv.wikipedia.org/wiki/Z70 but the dimensions are not strict, the wheel base has been shortened to assure that the train can cope with the rather short radius of 300mm used in my track and switch design. The body has been sculpted to pictures so it is not perfect scale either.

The aim was to create a easy-to-print locomotive that looks OK, but not a super complicated set with tons of parts. The kit includes mounting and pinion gear for using a standard RC-servo as motor. To do this you only need to pull out the potentiometer from the servo, adjust it so that it is in the middle, and then it a RC-signal will act as a dual way speed control. This is a slow but very easy method if you want to use very simple electronics or a radio control.

However, if you want better performance I recommend to use the included Arduino code, a motor controller board and a 16mm DC-motor with gearbox. You can find plenty of such motors on E-bay, or go to www.maxonmotor.com and configure a 16mm motor and gearbox. Direct drive will be too weak so you will need a gearbox.

To power the locomotive, you can either use the chassis which is prepared for batteries, or you can use the one adapted for LiPo-packs. In the first case, 4pcs AAA is used. In the case of LiPo-pack you can use a 2 cell series package (~7,2V).

Look further below for more detailed instructions!

Printer:

Prusa i3 mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Most parts are designed to be printed without support. The chassi and the body are the only parts on this page that requires support. Please see the instruction pictures for further information.

Building instructions
  • There are two versions of the chassi, one with the battery compartment prepared for 4pcs AAA-batteries and another one with an empty battery box if you want to use lipo cells for example.
  • Bearing houses are designed for ball bearings 6mm OD, 3mm ID, 2.5mm W.
    Screw them in place using M2x3.
  • Use M2x4 for the bumpers, if you use longer screws you'll have trouble with the screws for the body. (or you can glue the bumpers in place).
  • The body uses M2, length isn't critical, 6-10mm
  • Designed for use with 3mm shaft, I use carbon fiber rod. Cut them to 49mm length.
  • Placement of the wheels. The track width is 32mm, but you have to leave a gap in order for the train to be able to take the curves, I use 28mm between the inside of the wheels which works fine. The wheels are press-fit, so don't glue them and you'll be able to adjust this if needed.
  • Traction is created by using O-rings (or rubber bands) on the driving wheels.
  • The small "things" on the roof edges are holders for red 3mm LED's. The full scale locomotor has only white lights on the body, and uses red lights on the roof depending on which direction it travels. So, depending on how nerdy you want to be, you can use these mounts to get it "right". :)
  • In order to pull many cars, especially in a slope, you will need to add weight to get good enough grip. Otherwise the locomotive will just stand stil with the wheels turning. A good way to add weight is to buy weights designed for balancing car rims with. These can be bought in big packs at car part stores and usually have double-grip tape already on them. Put as many as you can fit in the locomotive!

Electronics

The included Arduino source code and schematic is for the Pro Micro-board. In the Arduino software, this board goes under the name Leonardo (which can be quite confusing). However, you can of course use any other Arduino compatible board with very little adaptation, you basically only need to change the pin allocation and make sure that the ports you choose can handle either PWM or analog in for respective ports. This board was chosen because of the compact size.

The motor board is a Dual TB6612FNG (1A) from Sparkfun.com

Source code descrpition
The included program uses a micro button switch to activate motion and a potentiometer (use between 5 - 10 kOhm ) to set speed. When the button is pressed, a counter starts counting either control loop (preset to 1/10S) and when the button is released, either forward or backward motion is initiated depending on how long the button is pressed. The motor PWM is increased with a pre-set acceleration value which you can adjust in the code if you want slower or faster acceleration.

At any given time during motion, the button can be pressed to initiate a deceleration. If the button is pressed longer than the pre-set emergency stop counter value, the PWM will be cut of as soon as the control loop has counted to that value with the button pressed.

During motion, the speed knob can be turned to directly adjust speed.

Resistors for LED's
In the schematic, the resistors for the LED's are not specified. This is because different supply voltage and different LED's will require different values. There is an easy way you can find out what value to use, without doing any calculations.

  1. Take a potentiometer and connect two wires, one to the middle (output) and one to either of the sides. Measure with a multimeter and turn the knob so you have maximum resistance dialed in (!important!).
  2. Wire up the LED's. In the case of front lights, there is almost always enough voltage to drive two of them in series unless you have a 3,3V CPU board like a NodeMCU, but most Arduinos can operate at 5V and then you will have enough voltage to put two LED's in series.
  3. Put the potentiometer in series with the two LED's and the multimeter set to current sensing mode.
  4. Connect a 4 cell battery (4,8V) or a power supply with 5V output).
  5. Slowly turn the potentiometer knob (lowering the resistance) until the LED's shine bright enough, or you reach around 20mA of current, which is standard nominal for most simpler LED's (not high-power ones). Also keep in mind that if you intend to drive them directly from a digital I/O on the Arduino, it's very important to make sure they don't draw too much current!. 20mA is OK for most boards so aim for that. IF you read this and think it's stupid not to just use a simple Ohms law, keep in mind that in many cases you want the LED to shine less bright than full power, then this is a good way to adapt and make it shine exactly the way you want it to.

Alternative, powering LED's from motor board
As briefly stated in the schematics, the motor board can handle two motor outputs and only one is used for the motor. The other one can be used for LED's, but keep in mind that the output at full PWM duty cycle will supply the whole battery voltage unregulated, this mean that the LED's will shine brighter at first and gradually shine less bright as the battery voltage decreases. That said, you can still use the boards H-bridge in a smart way to light up either sides headlights without any extra pins on the arduino, here is how.

  1. Follow the above instructions for the LED's and the resistors, but in this case use your intended batterypack as voltage source when testing.

  2. Now to the important part, wire the head ligths like this:
    Forward -------->---- Board---<------- Backwards
    LED voltage ---->---- B01 ----<------- LED GND
    LED GND ------->---- B02 ----<------- LED Voltage

Why this connection? The LED's are diodes, meaning they will block current in one direction and allow current in the other. They are not harmed by reverse voltage as long as it's not higher than they are designed for. In the above connection, depending on which of B01 or B02 is voltage or GND, only one sides head lights will shine at either one time.

  1. Next step is to bridge the direction inputs to control this as well. Connect as followes:
    AIN1 -> BIN1
    AIN2 -> BIN2

  2. If you want to be able to dim the lights, connect an extra PWM output from the Arduino to the PWMB-input on the motor board. If you are OK with full power or nothing, just connect VCC to PWMB and you're set. (do NOT use VM, because that input has higher voltage than the controller can handle).

Finally, there are a lot of directions to keep track of here which can be a bit confusing, so before you mount the boards in the locomotive, fire it up and test. If the lights are wrong, either switch place for the B01 and B02 or connect AIN1 to BIN2 and AIN2 to BIN1. If on the other hand, the directions forward and backward are wrong compared to the chassis, switch place on the motor leads instead.

author: BrickFrog

print_settings.Notes:: For the material it depends on what your end goal is. If you want to end up almost fully enclosed then you'll need to use ABS or perhpas ASA. If you don't want fully enclosed then PLA or PETG would be fine. Personally i'm running all PETG at the moment. It will probably be fine once enclosed too but ABS is a safer bet.

description.text:
Want to know more about the design and assembly process?
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWL37f39O8e8jSmrYGKiWX6iMkNlrfwSp

Join the Facebook Group for discussion + Q&A + Future updates and upgrades
https://www.facebook.com/groups/266957403761491/

See the full Bill of Materials with supplied links here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1FVdSh7WRvvxo3kc_i1Jvbl6kwNt3XSbQIA1PcNw0xOk/edit#gid=0 (some affiliate links included but buy from wherever you feel comfortable)

S.T.E.V.E is an open source, single extruder, easy to modify 3D printer with a approx 240mm cubed build volume and CoreXY Kinematics. When starting to design S.T.E.V.E I just wanted to learn more about the CoreXY kinematics but things got out of hand, one thing lead to another, and I ended up designing an entire printer that I wanted to share.

He was designed with the intention of every part being easy to purchase or print, and easy to build with assistance of detailed instructions with very little needed in terms of tools. (For best results a drill and 3.5mm bit plus crimping tool for red crimp terminals would be ideal. You can probably survive without.) The obvious allen keys are also needed.

Instructions are currently in the form of PDF drawings and an extensive video guide. All the video links are down below. Some show some information about the design process, while the others explain how to assemble the printer.

One of S.T.E.V.E's most unique features is the gantry head assembly. It ensures that the centre of mass of the stepper motor is aligned as closely as possible to the rods to reduce torque on the bearings and improve print quality. The same assembly provides a modular system for adding, changing or removing different features from around the hot end such as cable management, fans, bed sensors etc.

While this isn't a remix, i'll give some credit to Tech2C and his hypercube printer. I did borrow a couple of design aspects such as the clamps used for round rods.

Frame

S.T.E.V.E's frame is constructed from standard 6mm slot 2020 aluminium extrusion, held together with M5 x 8mm Button head screws and 90 degree angle brackets. All easy to get and easy to assemble.

One key design feature of S.T.E.V.E is that all the components are kept within the rigid 2020 aluminium frame so that it is simple to enclose the printer to form a heated chamber for printing of more exotic materials. (heat resistant plastic parts also recommended)

Steppers

S.T.E.V.E uses a total of 5 NEMA 17 stepper motors, a 13Ncm pancake stepper for the extruder, 4 45Ncm D shaft steppers for the X, Y and Z motion.

Control Board

The selected control board for version 0.1 of S.T.E.V.E is the RAMPS 1.4. This will be upgraded in the future as RAMPS was mostly for prototyping.

Heated Bed

The bed is 6mm tool plate aluminium which is ideal as it has high thermal conductivity and won’t warp overtime becuase of the way it was manufactured. The Heating is provided by a 330W 230V silicon heater with a built in thermal cut off at 180C for safety (set RAMPS max to 150C).

SSR

Because the bed heater is powered through mains voltage a Solid state relay is used to control power to the bed. The low voltage side of the SSR is attached to the control board as normal and acts like a switch.

Hotend and Extruder

S.T.E.V.E uses the E3D v6 full metal universal hot end and titan extruder with a 13Ncm stepper motor to provide a lightweight, versatile and reliabile print head.

Power Supply

Since the power supply is only for the stepper motors and hot end, there is no need for 300-400W power supplies. A high quality 12V unit that can supply 80-100W should be more than enough. Closet to 100W if you want some LEDs in there too.

Special Note: Recently i have noticied that the aluminium rods for X and Y are a little too flexible. I am going to test putting Steel rods on the Y axis and see how that does. Might have to upgrade the X axis to 10mm Aluminium or 8mm steel for rigidity. Will keep you updated.

Special Note 2: Not sure what makes these notes special but i have tested with 8mm steel on the X and Y axis. I have had good results with 8mm steel rods on both axis.

Printer:

Any Printer will do

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2-0.3mm

Infill:

30-50%

Notes:

I'm not going to list precise details for how to print every part. They are all fairly simple geometric shapes with quite obvious indications of how they should be printed. I printed all of mine without support so you should be fine to do that too. Try to print all the load bearing parts with a good infill to ensure they will be strong enough.

For the material it depends on what your end goal is. If you want to end up almost fully enclosed then you'll need to use ABS or perhpas ASA. If you don't want fully enclosed then PLA or PETG would be fine. Personally i'm running all PETG at the moment. It will probably be fine once enclosed too but ABS is a safer bet.

S.T.E.V.E is my first full 3D printer creation.

The name stands for Superfluous Tri-dimensional Electronic Vector Extruder. The name came about when asking the 3D printing facebook group for name suggestions (yes i know, never ask the internet for name suggestions!) My two favourite suggestions were the name Steve, and making an accronym name such as JACP; Just Another Corexy Printer. So I decided to combine them into a single item and thus S.T.E.V.E was born.

V0.01

In the files list there a BOM file. A full list of parts needed for the base spec of S.T.E.V.E. I highly recommend you take a look at the PDF drawing files to get an idea of what is used where. If you want to use slightly different bearings then the PDF drawings are also a great way to get an idea of what you need to change.

Version Notes

X Gantry End v0.2 - Slightly increased M3 clearance hole sizes and thickness around idlers. Not compatible with X Gantry Bearing Clamp v0.01.

X Gantry Bearing Clamp v0.2 - Split into two parts. Improved clearance to enclosure walls. Easier to print. Print in orientation provided. 4 required.

Marlin Firmware v0.2 - Added feature to use second extruder output on RAMPS as second Z motor and fixed some bugs.

X Gantry End - LM8LUU_0.2 - improved version of the LM8UU X gantry end. only minor changes. backwards compatible. New Bearing clamps needed.

X Gantry Bearing Clamp - LM8LUU_0.2 - Required for X Gantry End - LM8LUU_0.2. Lower profile two part bearing clamp for each end of the X Gantry.

Gantry Head LM8LUU Bearing Holder_0.2 - Bearing clamps for the X axis gantry that use LM8lUU instead of IGUS bearings. Use one LM8LUU and one LM8UU

Mods

Here are some of the mods for STEVE that you might want to try if you think the standard design is not quite right for you. I have not tested them personally so if you need assistance, speak to the mod/remix designer.

E3D V6 Bowden Mount

If you want to use an e3d v6 bowden setup with STEVE, this mod will allow you to attach directly to the stepper motor mount with additional support for a bed sensor and part cooling fan.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2333612

XY Joiner for 10mm Gantry rods and IGUS RJZM bushes

If you want to upgrade the X axis gantry to 10mm rods, leaving the Y axis with 8mm then this is what you need to do it.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2363021

X and Y Modified Endstop

If you don't like the standard positioning of the STEVE endstops, why not try this mod that allows the Y end stop to be mounted directly to the frame, and the X endstop to be mounted on the X gantry itself.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2378271

A-senco SSR-500 case

If you opt for a slightly different model of SSR then you might find this mod helpful as the original one might be just a little too tight.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2378306

12 mm Z Axis Shaft with LM12LUU

I have made a 12mm Z axis option, everything else about it is the same, just the larger diameter. Print the equivalent parts with '12mm' in the name. There are two modified files for this.

comments.text:
Hey, I love your design, but I'm in the process of building a large printer and I'm looking at the best way to mount my e3d titan with v6 extruder as well. Because of the nature of big printers, it means I will have longer prints and more filament needed, therefore I'm going to use 5kg filament spools. I saw you switched out the extruder motor to a pancake stepper, my first question is if the little pancake motor could pull the 5kg spool? And if not could I still use the bigger 1.8 stepper without problems ? Or what would be your suggestion?
Thanks
comments.author: Machoo566

comments.text: The stepper is not about pulling, its about pushing. Mounting the spool properly should result in very little resistance to rotation so the stepper will be fine. Make sure to use a guidance tube, a bit like bowden, so that the motion is not pulling the filament. just the stepper.

comments.text: I understand your decision to not release Solidworks the source files. Would you consider releasing each part as a STEP (stp) file?  The problem with converting an STL back is that all circles/radii/curves are turned into line segments which are a real pain to deal with.  Saving as a STEP file keeps it as a dummy solid but with correct circles/radii/curves. This also enables other CAD systems to read them. Hope you consider this. Cheers.

MakerBot Replicator+

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

10%

Notes:

Pretty much default settings worked. I printed it with the screw holes on the print plate - but I think with the groove down would work as well.

print_settings.Notes:: These are the general settings for this thing.  I actually used a layer height of 0.2258mm on my MPCNC because it allows full steps with the Z screw.  I also opted for 40% infill to make it stronger.  Combined with the lateral orientation, de-lamination should not be an issue.  The object prints fine in it's current orientation - although you may have a little cleanup on the inner-top of the path area, depending on how good your printer creates bridges.

description.text: This is a simple filament guide that clips on to the edge of a 3/4" shelf. It's designed to allow the filament to run smoothly from a spool holder on a shelf above the printer. I found that my spool roller functions much better with the path going directly down instead of at an angle. This is easily scalabe in your slicer to fit different shelf sizes and has no effect on print quality or function.

Printer:

MPCNC

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.22

Infill:

20%

Notes:

These are the general settings for this thing. I actually used a layer height of 0.2258mm on my MPCNC because it allows full steps with the Z screw. I also opted for 40% infill to make it stronger. Combined with the lateral orientation, de-lamination should not be an issue. The object prints fine in it's current orientation - although you may have a little cleanup on the inner-top of the path area, depending on how good your printer creates bridges.
The original part didn't work because it broke. the piece that I designed and printed worked perfectly. the kickstand fit perfectly into the cut out on the plate.

author: k0l9khv

description.text:
I purchased a FreeLSS Board from user C_D and the only complaint I had was it is difficult to mount in my enclosure. I opted not to use the standard Piclop design that is out there and designed my own since this device now runs my printer via Octoprint and does a few other functions as well. One change I made was adding some lights to the front, which required a relay as well. This thing includes three files:

  1. freelssMount_only.stl - A mount for the FreeLSS Board only. It has three mounting holes and an area where the board snaps in. The mounting holes use m3 style screws.

  2. freelssMount_2ch.stl - A mount for the FreeLSS Board and a "Sainsmart" style 2ch relay board. It has three mounting holes, an area for the FreeLSS board to snap in, and a mount area for the relay board with raised mounting holes. The mounting holes use m3 style screws for the mount and for the relay board.

  3. freelssMount_screwholes.stl - Three cylinders of the proper size aligned with the mounting holes. Designed to allow you to easily punch the holes in your enclosure design for mounting the board. This is not meant to be printed, just used for a boolean to create the holes to mount it. The holes in the mount are 2.4mm which is tight for an m3 but enough to hold the screws in place. I mounted the boards to the mount, started the mounting screws, and then placed the mount in the enclosure and tightened it down. This prevented dropping the screws inside. The screw hole pattern provided is three 2.2mm cylinders, which makes the mount holes in the enclosure a bit tighter.

This can be printed laying oriented as the stl loads, with the top up. No supports are needed.

Might need improvements, it was a rush job. I drilled  breathing holes and holes for the rubberband to keep it on my head. Also padded the edge a bit with foam to make it less painfull to wear. Also i didn't have time to paint it so I used skincolored medicaltape.

description.text:
This is a Holder + Case for a Raspberry Pi with a 3.5 TFT Display.
It should fit very snugly on to the frame of the Orginal Prusa i3.
The holder arms are meant to snap in to the case but this did not work as i expected.
Instead i just glued it in place because of time constraints.
Maybe i will improve the design if enough people are interested in that.
The main Case was remixed of the PI TFT case from Adafruit
( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1601055 ).
Also check out there tutorial to the 3.5 PiTFT Octoprint Rig
( https://learn.adafruit.com/3-dot-5-pitft-octoprint-rig/overview ).
If you have any questions please do not hesitate to ask me.
Don't forget to tell me about your prints in the Comments and leave a picture of your setup.
Happy Printing !

Printer:

Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Try to print the Parts like on the Screenshot of Slic3r above.

• 1x Bot case
  • 1x Top case
  • 2x Holder Arm

comments.text: For whatever reason I cant close shut the Pi+Adafruit TFT with this enclosure, the upper left corner keeps opening (having the USBs looking to the right), I even tried to cut the peg that keeps the Pi in place but still wont help....
comments.author: bolsoncerrado

comments.text:
@bolsoncerrado
I know about this issue i had similar problems.
It's not coused by the pegs that hold the PI.
The closing Design just isn't very reliable.
I already thought about replacing it with screw holes but I curently do not have enough time for that.
Howewer I will try to do this in the next month since I see that my design is getting very popular and keep you updated .
If you would like to modify it by yourself I have uploaded the source file so you can try to fix it with fusion 360
(if you do, don't foreget to share it ;) )

comments.text: Which touch screen did you use? would this one fit?
comments.author: c_wolsey

comments.text:
I used this one :
http://www.banggood.com/3_5-Inch-320-X-480-TFT-LCD-Display-Touch-Board-For-Raspberry-Pi-2-Model-B-RPI-B-p-1023432.html?rmmds=myorder

title: FlashForge Dreamer Lid with Filament Guide
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
After buy my Flashforge Dreamer, I printed side support for spools - and I used this thing:

Dremel Idea Builder Filament Spindle
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1737409

To filament get inside the printer I need print lids to rise the print cover, so I found this thing:

FlashForge Dreamer Lid Spacer 13,7mm by PeterS1, published May 14, 2016

I remix this lid and merge filament guide, look the pictures.

You need:

  • 2 Lid Spacer without guide (to front) - lid.stl
  • 2 Lid Spacer with guide (to rear) - lid_with_guide.stl

After print the lid spacer with guide, use small pieces of teflon tube 4mm (od) and 2mm (id) to smooth filament flow. Maybe you need enlarge the holes a bit, I left tight to hold teflon tubes in place.

Printer:

FlashForge Dreamer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

100 microns

Infill:

40%
